div.p: OF THE BLASPHEMIE Against the HOLY-GHOST.
Printed in the Yeare, 1646.

div.head: Of the Blasphemie against the HOLY GHOST.
div.p:
MAny have written of the Sinne against the Holy Ghost, who in defining or describing of it, follow onely their owne zealous conceits, and not the Canon of holy Scripture: The more dreadfull the sinne is, the fearfuller we must be in the charging, or fixing of it upon any speciall Crime, or particular person. In the definition of a sinne of so heinous a nature, direct and evident proof of Scripture is requisit. It is not enough to consider (as many doe) what sinnes are most desperate, and deadly, and then to conclude, that such sinnes are sinnes against the H â€¢ ly Ghost: Thus indeed the Schoole-men have done, who have made six differences of this sinne, without any colour of ground, or warrant in Scripture for so doing: And Bellarmine is so liberall in bestowing this sinne against the Holy Ghost upon such as he calls Heretiques, that his opinion is, That a man can scarce be a learned Protestant, without committing the sinne against the Holy Ghost; Neither are the Papists the onely men that have beene mistaken about this
sinne, but too many Divines of the Reformed Churches have started a side from the Scripture, and given us such intricate and contradictory definitions of this sinne, as tend onely to the perplexing of the tender consciences of weake Christians. To make good this censure, I will briefly set downe so much touching this sin, as I conceive is warranted by the Word of God, and humbly submit it to the Judgement of the Learned.

div.head: The Blasphemie against the Holy Ghost, was an evill speaking or slandering of the Miracles of our Saviour Christ, by those, who though they were convinced by the Miracles, to believe that such Workes could not be done but by the Power of God; yet they did maliciously say, they were wrought by the Power of the Divell.
div.p: In this description, these points are observable:

First, I forbeare to call it the sinne, but name it
the Blasphemie against the Holy Ghost: for though every blasphemy be a sinne in the generall, yet our Saviour Christ tearmes it onely the blasphemy, and the Evangelists doe all agree, to give it onely the same tearme; and it is no where in all the Scripture called the sinne against the Holy Ghost: and yet it appeares, both in Saint Mathew, and Saint Mark, that there was just occasion offered for our Saviour to have named it the sin against the Holy Ghost; where he compares, with the sinne against the Sonne of Man: but he forbeares to call it any thing but, the Blasphemie against the Holy Ghost: Thereby no doubt, to teach us, that it consists onely in cursed speaking, or blaspheming. A serious consideration of this point, may teach us so much moderation, as to confine our selves to that tearme which our Saviour in three Evangelists hath prescribed unto us. I cannot find, that any man that hath yet written of this Argument, hath made any observation, or noted this const â€¢ nt phrase and tearme used by the Evangelists, in pronouncing the dreadfull sentence of our Saviour against Blasphemers of the Holy Ghost: I will therefore cite all those Texts, where the Blaspheming against the Holy Ghost is named: Mathew 12.31. All manner of Sinne and Blasphemy shalbe forgiven unto men, but the Blasphemy against the Holy Ghost.

Mark. 3. 28. All sines shal be forgiven the Sonnes of men, and Blasphemies wherewith soever they blaspheme; but he that shall blaspheme against the Holy Ghost, hath never forgivenesse, but is in danger of eternall damnation.
Luke 12.10. Whosoever shall speake a word against the sonne of man, it shall be forgiven him, but u â€¢ to him that blasphemeth against the Holy Ghost, it shall not be forgiven him.

Secondly, a second observation is, that Blaspheming is a speaking against an ther, as both Saint Mathew and Saint Luke expound the word; for in the originall it is, a hurting or blasting the fame, or blaming of another; for, from the Greeke word Blaspheme, both the French, Blasme Biasimo
Italian, and our English, by contraction, have made our word Blame. Blame

Thirdly, to passe from the name, to the thing it selfe, wee may observe by the coherence of the Texts, that the Blasphemie against the Holy Ghost was spoken by our blessed Saviour concerning the Scribes and Pharisees, for Saint Mark tells us in plaine tearmes the reason was, because the Pharisees said, he had an uncleane spirit: For, when they saw our Saviour cast out a Divell, blind and dumb, to the amazement of the people, they said, he cast out the Divell by Belzebub, the Prince of Divels: This speech of the Pharisees, whereby they slandered his Miracles wrought by the power of the Holy Ghost, is properly the Blasphemie against the Holy Ghost. How transcendent a Crime it was, to traduce that power by which our Saviour wrought his Miracles, may thus appeare.

The end for which Miracles were wrought, was most evidently to prove, that Iesus was the Messias, that the multitude beholding with their eyes the workes which he wrought, might thereby be led
to believe the doctrine which he taught; there be store of Texts to prove this: The workes I doe in my Fathers name, beare witnesse of me; If I doe not the workes of my Father, believe me not; though you believe not me, believe the workes, John 10. John 14. Believe me, that I am in the Father, or else believe me for the very workes sake. When the Disciples of John asked, Art thou he? Iesus answered, Goe shew Iohn those things which you see and heare, the blind receive their sight, the lame walke, Mathew 11. When the multitude beheld his Miracles, they mervailed, and said, It was never so seene in Israel; since the world began was it not heard, that any man opened the eyes of one borne blind, John 9. A woman could say, Come see a man that told me all things, Is this the Christ? John 4.29. So they that saw the Miracles of the Loaves, could say, Is this that Prophet which is to come? Nicodemus the Pharisee saith, Rabbi, no man can doe those things that thou dost, except God be with him. These and other places shew, that the working of Miracles was an act of the most glorious manifestation of the power and Majestie of God, by which at the first even the simplest of men were led by their outward sense, to that great mysterie of inward Faith in Christ their Redeemer. Therefore, for those men who were eyewitnesses of such Miracles, as did make them know that Christ was a Teacher come from God, to blaspheme that Power by which those Miracles were wrought, and to say, they were done by the helpe of the Divell, was the most despitefull and malicious slander that could be invented; for thereby
they attempted, as much as in them lay, to destroy the very Principles of Faith, and to prevent the first propagation of the Gospell, to the universall mischiefe of all man-kind: And though these Pharisees were no Christians, and therefore could not fall away from Faith, which they never had, yet they did know and believe, that Christ was a Teacher come from God; for so our Saviour tells them, Iohn 7.28. Ye both know me, and whence I am. They did not believe in him as a Saviour, but as a great Prophet from God, as the Mahumetans doe at this day: They trusted to be saved by their Law, and because he taught such things as did abrogate their Law, in which they so much gloried, they were so malicious to his Doctrine, which they did not believe, that they did speake evill of his Miracles, which they did believe; lest the people, by approving of his Miracles, should have Faith in his Doctrine.

Fourthly, observe; It is said to be the Blasphemie against the Holy Ghost, because by the power of the Spirit, or Holy Ghost, the Miracles were wrought: for our Saviour saith, Mathew 10.28. If I cast out Divells by the Spirit of God; and Saint Paul teacheth us, that the working of Miracles is by the same spirit, 1. Cor. 12.

Fifthly, the Blasphemie against the Sonne of man was, when men considered Christ as a meere man, and did disgracefully taxe his conversation, by saying, Behold a glutton, a bibber of Wine, a friend to Publicans and Sinners: but, The Blasphemie against the Holy Ghost was, when men beholding Christs Miracles, did enviously
ascribe those workes to the Divell, which they did know and believe to be done by the Power of God.

Sixthly, these Texts formerly recited out of the three Evangelists, being all the places wherein the Blasphemie against the Holy-Ghost is named; wee cannot find by them, that wee have any safe rule to conclude, that any but the Scribes and Pharisees, or their confederates, committed the Blasphemie against the Holy-Ghost: I dare not say, that Iudas, or those that stoned Stephen, or Iulian the Apostate, or Simon Magus, were any of them guilty of this detestable Blasphemie.

Seventhly, The Apostles have not in any of their Epistles once mentioned this Blasphemie against the Holy-Ghost, and yet they were most carefull and frequent in dehortations from all sorts of sinne; it were much, they should forget, or omit such a fearefull Crime, without often and most precise admonishing us to beware of it: And though negative proofes from Scripture are not demonstrative, yet the generall silence of the Apostles may at least helpe to inferre a probability, that the Blasphemie against the Holy-Ghost is not a sinne committable by any Christian that lived not in the time of our Saviour.

THere be three places or Texts in the Epistles, wherein although the Blasphemie against the Holy-Ghost
be not named, yet most thinke it is intended and meant in each of those places: And Bellarmine (in confuting Saint Austins opinion, who held that finall impenitencie was the sinne against the Holy-Ghost) affirmes, that it seemes the three Texts in the Epistles, are spoken of the sinne against the Holy-Ghost; and yet this great Cardinall forgetting what he hath said in the same Chapter, contradicteth himselfe, and shewes how that these three places are not to be expounded of that sinne. I will cite the Texts, and then his interpretation of them, according to the exposition of Saint Ambrose, Saint Chrysostome, Saint Ierom, and other Fathers, as he saith:

The first Text is, Hebrewes 6.4. It is impossible for they who were once enlightnedâ€”if they shall fall away, to renew them againe to repentance, seeing they Crucifie to themselves the Sonne of God afresh: The Apostle here speakes onely of repentance, which did goe before Baptisme; for so Chrysostome, Ambrose, and other Fathers expound it: which the Apostle insinuates,
First, in those words [who were once enlightned] that is, Baptized; for antiently to be illuminated, signified to be Baptized.
Secondly, in those words [to renew againe] for wee are properly renewed in Baptisme.

Thirdly, in those words [crucifying the Sonne of God afresh] for when we are baptized, wee are conformed to the likenesse of his death, Rom. â€¢ 6.
and as Christ was onely once crucified, so also wee are onely once baptized; and he that will be againe baptized, should againe crucifie to himselfe Christ. Let me adde this, that in the verses going next before this Text, the Apostles speakes of the Foundation of Repentance, and the Doctrine of Baptismes; and in this Text, our new translation followes Beza, who hath varied from the Originall, by putting the conditionall (si, if) in stead of the copulative (et, and) and by adding the causall (ut:) so that whereas Beza and our translation is,
Si prolabantur â€” ut qui crucifigant;
If they fall away â€” seeing they crucifie:

The Greeke and vulgar Latine is,
ã€ˆ in non-Latin alphabet ã€‰ â€” ã€ˆ in non-Latin alphabet ã€‰ ,
Et prolapsi suntâ€”crucifigentes;
And fallingâ€”Crucifying againe.
For the word doth not signifie to fall away, but to fall casually, or negligently: so ã€ˆ in non-Latin alphabet ã€‰ , Gal. 6. is translated a fault, and not a falling away.

The second Text is, Heb. 10.26. For if wee sinne willingly, or wilfully, after wee have received the knowledge of the Truth, there remaineth no more Sacrifice for Sinne. Answ. I say with Chrysostome, Ambrose, and
other Fathers, the sense is, wee must not expect another Christ to dye for us, or that he who hath once died, should come againe to dye for us.

The third Text is, 1 Iohn 5.16. There is a Sinne unto Death, I doe not say yee shall pray for it: Saint Ierome saith, that nothing else is heere meant, but that a Prayer for a sinne unto death, is very hardly or difficultly heard: and this seemes to be the truest sense of this place; for Saint Iohn saith immediately before, wee know that wee have the Petitions that wee desired of him: therefore least wee should thinke this to hold true in all Petitions whatsoever, which wee offer for others, he addes; If any man see his Brother sinne a sinne, which is not unto Death, he shall aske, and he shall give him life: that is, let him aske with Confidence, for he shall obtaine: but if it be a sinne unto Death, th â€¢ t is, a great sinne, such an one as is not ordinarily pardoned, but punished with Death, I doe not say yee shall pray for it; that is, I doe not prohibit you to pray, but I dare not promise that you shall easily obtaine; therefore, I doe not say yee shall pray, that is, with that confiden â€¢ e of obtaining: for often, in such cases, God doth not heare the Prayers of the Saints; as God saith, Ier. 7.16. Pray not thou for this people, for I will not heare thee.

If these expositions upon the former Tears be sound, the definition of the sinne against the Holy-Ghost cannot be grounded upon all, or any of
them; for, as it is not once named, so it cannot be intended in any of them: he that will find fault with these interpretations, it is reason he should bring better, and more agreeable to the literall sense and coherence and scope of Text, and such I should gladly learne.

It seemes the probability of the exposition of the first place, Heb. 6. is so great, that a learned Divine, who produceth this Text, for proofe of his definition of the sinne against the Holy-Ghost, doth confesse against himselfe, that the Apostle in this place denyeth a second Baptisme, when he speakes of Repentance, because they are mentioned together in the same place, and have some affinity and correspondence.

As for the second Text, Heb. 10. I must confesse, that if Saint Paul in this place meant the sinne against the Holy-Ghost, that then this were the onely desperate Text in the whole Bible; for what man is there that si â€¢ nes not willingly? for so the word ã€ˆ in non-Latin alphabet ã€‰ doth properly signifie: Beza translates it ultro, the vulgar Latine voluntarie, voluntarily, or willingly, not wilfully and obstinately: It is but a miserable comfort, when Saint Paul saith, if wee sinne willingly, for Master Calvin to tell us, that the Text doth not meane every willing sinne, but onely a malicious resisting of the Truth: could not Saint Paul, as easily as Master Calvin, have said, if wee sinne maliciously, as say, if wee sinne willingly?
My comfort is, that if the Text be advisedly considered, there is no such thing as the sinne against the Holy-Ghost, or any other desperate conclusion to be found in the Text: the scope of the precedent verses, doe evidently expound the Apostles meaning to be this; to let the Jewes know, that the case was not now with them, as it was under the Law; for under the Law they had dayly sacrifices for sinnes, but now, under the Gospel, they had but one sacrifice once for all: every Priest standeth dayly ministring, and offering oftentimes the same Sacrifice; but this man, after he had offered one Sacrifice, for ever sat downe at the right hand of God, as it is in the eleventh verse of the same Chapter; which may serve for a Comment upon the verse now in question: and it is worth our noting, that the Text doth not say, if wee sinne willingly, there is no Sacrifice; this had beene a hard saying indeed: but the words are, there remaines no more Sacrifice: there is some comfortable difference, I hope, betweene these two propositions; there is no Sacrifice, and, there remaines no more Sacrifice: so that if wee doe not believe in that one Sacrifice as sufficient, but looke every day for a new Sacrifice for every new sinne, wee must expect nothing but Iudgement.

As to the third place, 1 Iohn 5.16. Many would conclude, that there is a sinne for which wee may not pray, because it is irremissible, and this they thinke must needs be the sinne against the Holy-Ghost
meant by Saint Iohn: their best Argument is, that Iohns not saying that wee shall pray, is a saying, that wee shall not pray; his silence is to them a prohibition: But this is bad Grammar, and worse Logique; for wee find that Saint Stephen prayed for them that stoned him, and yet told them that they resisted the Holy-Ghost; and Saint Peter exhorted Simon Magus to repentance, and yet both he and those that stoned Stephen, are commonly reputed sinners against the Holy Ghost: Saint Ambrose is of that charitable judgement, that he thinks the sinne against the Holy-Ghost may be pardoned by repentance; because the people of the Iewes, who had said of Christ, he casts out the Divell by Belzebub, the prince of Divells; afterwards, at the preaching of Saint Peter, are said to be converted, in the second of the Acts. Saint Austine in his Retractations concludes, that wee must despaire of no man, no not of the wickedest, as long as he lives, and wee way safely pray for him of whom wee doe not despaire: for though it be expressely said, that the Blasphemie against the Holy-Ghost shall not be forgiven; yet these words may justly receive a qualification, if wee will but allow the same mitigation of the sense of these words, which all men confesse wee must needes allow to the precedent words in the same verse, to which these have relation; where it is said generally, All Sinnes and all Blasphemies shall be forgiven to men: it cannot mea â€¢ e, that all sinnes, all wayes, and to all men, for then no sinne could be damnable, but the Blasphemie against the Holy-Ghost; which is
most false: and therefore the sense must be, all sinnes shall be forgiven ordinarily, or for the most p â€¢ rt; so on the contrary, the Blasphemie against the Holy-Ghost shall not ordinarily, or hardly be forgiven. Even those that are most strict, for to maintaine the sinne against the Holy-Ghost to be unpardonable, will yet acknowledge, that sometimes in Scripture an impossibility is used to note a difficulty, and those things are spoken indefinitely of all, which properly belong to a part onely: thus the difficultie of the rich mans entring into the Kingdome of Heaven, is presented unto us by our Saviour, under the similitude of an impossibilitie.

HAving dispatched these Texts of Scripture, which doe either name, or are thought to concerne the Blasphemie, or Sinne against the Holy-Ghost; it remaines to examine all those common definitions of this sinne, which are now currant: and though there be some difference among Divines in the tearmes, by which they define it; some calling it a totall, or finall falling from Faith, or a wilfull apostasie, or a malicious resisting of the Truth: yet, when they all come to explaine their meaning, the difference among them is not considerable.

I shall therefore chiefly apply my selfe to examine Master Calvins definition, because his judgement
hath gained the greatest reputation amongst the multitude: As for that, he himselfe promiseth such a true definition, which shall easily by it selfe overthrow all the rest: in his Institutions, lib. 3. cap. 3. he saith, They sinne against the Holy-Ghost, Qui divinae veritatis (cujus fulgore sic perst â€¢ inguntur ut ignorantiam causari nequeant) tamen destinata malitia resistunt in hoc tantum ut resistant.

The Rhetoricall Parenthesis (which might well have beene spared in a definition) being reduced into plaine and briefe tearmes, this definition of Master Calvin may be thus in English: They sinne against the Holy-ghost, â€¢ ho of determined malice resist the known truth of God to the end onely to resist.

In this definition, Master Calvin doth not define what the Sinne is, but who they are that commit it; whereas by the Rules of Logick, Concretes admit of no true definition, but onely Abstracts. But taking the definition as it is, it consists principally upon these three tearmes: First, Truth: Secondly, Known: Thirdly, Resisted, or a resisting of the knowne Truth. These words being generall and doubtfull tearmes, I shall consider them severally.

First, If by the Truth of God, Master Calvin doe understand the Word of God, or the whole Doctrine of God revealed in Scripture, then the sense of this tearme will be too large: For even the Pharisees that spake against the Holy-Ghost, did not resist the whole Truth of God in the Scripture, for they believed in the Law of Moses, and had confidence to be saved by observing of it; and in defence of that Law (as they thought) they did blaspheme the Holy-Ghost. Therefore
properly by the Truth of God, Master Calvin must confine his meaning to the truth of the Gospel, or doctrine of Faith; for so both he himselfe and others expound themselves, by tearming the Sinne against the Holy-Ghost, a falling away or turning away from faith, or apostasie.
Secondly, by this word Knowne, Master Calvin must meane believed; for faith is properly by beleeving, and not by knowing the truth.

Thirdly, The word Resisting must meane unbeleeving; For if the receiving the Truth be by beliefe, then resisting of it must be by unbeliefe: and indeed so Master Calvin explaines himselfe in the same chapter, saying, There is no place for pardon where knowledge is joyned with unbeliefe; Non esse veniae locum ubi scientia ad incredulitatem accessit. So then, by this definition, to resist the Knowne Truth is all one, as if Master Calvin would have said, in proper and significant tearmes, for a man at once to unbelieve that which he doth believe: which two things it is impossible for any man to doe together; and if they be not together, there can be no resistance.

It is true, that for some reasons somtimes a man may be brought not to beleeve that which he formerly believed; but this cannot be in an instant, but successively unbeliefe comes in the place of beliefe: and this may not be called resisting; for that a â€¢ l resistance consists in a violence between two at the least: but where two succeed one another, and are never together, it cannot possibly be. I confesse, a man may resist the truth, when it is either a truth in it selfe onely, or in the understanding of some other;
but to resist the truth which is knowne, which is beleeved by the resister himselfe, is a direct contradiction: For the nature of truth is such, that if the understanding doe apprehend it for true, it cannot but assent unto it; No man can force himselfe to beleeve what he lists, or when he lists: Sometimes a man knowes not what to beleeve, but finds a suspension of his faith, or a trepidation of his understanding, not discerning which way to turne; this cannot bee called a resisting of the Kn â€¢ wne Truth, where the truth is not knowne, but doubted of.

Againe, some truths there be, which although they bee assented unto by the understanding for truths, yet they are not desired as good: for truth is one degree neerer of affinitie to the soule of man then goodnesse: The Pharis â€¢ es did apprehend the Miracles of our Saviour as true, but not as good, because they tended to the derogation of their Law, which they esteemed a better truth; and for this cause they blasphemed that truth, which in their hearts they beleeved to be true: For, the truth of words or speech is (as the Schooles say) nothing else but the signe of truth, and not truth it selfe; for truth it selfe is seated in the understanding, and not in speech. That truth which the understanding assents unto, the speech may affirme to bee false; there are many things beleeved in Deed, which are denyed in word; but such denyall is not a resisting, but onely a making shew of resistance of truth: For the resistance must be in the same place where the truth is: truth being seated in the understanding, the resistance must be placed there also; the
understanding can resist no truth, but by unbeleeving onely.

If Master Calvin had intended a resisting of the truth onely in word, he had come one step neerer to the truth of the Scripture; but he was not so happy in the expression of his meaning: Nay, his tearmes of incredulitie, apostasie, falling away, and the like, relate to a reall, and not a verball apostasie and unbeliefe.

It remaines then to my understanding, that Master Calvin makes the resisting of the Truth to be a not believing of that which wee doe believe: which being a contradiction, he defines the sinne against the Holy-Ghost to be such a sinne, as no man possibly can commit. And yet on the other extreame, in expounding his owne definition, he makes it such a sinne as no man living but commits; for by his Doctrine (as I take it) any sinne may be the sinne against the Holy-Ghost; his words are these: Quorum convicta esse conscientia, verbum Dei esse quod repudiant, et impugnant, impugnare tamen non desinunt, illi in, spiritum blasphemari dicuntur; They are said to blaspheme the Spirit, whose consciences are convinced that it is the Word of God, which they forsake and impugne, and yet cease not to impugne it.

What man is there, that doth not daily in some point or other forsake the Word of God, and ceases not to impugne it, and is convinced thereof in his conscience? I know Master Calvin was farre from thinking, that Saint Paul did sinne against the Holy-Ghost; yet Saint Paul was convinced it seemes in his
conscience, that it was the word of God which he did fight against, and yet ceased not to fight against it, when he saith: he delighted in the Law of God, yet another Law warring against the Law of his mind, brought him into Captivitie to the Law of sinne. What dangerous inferences weake consciences may draw upon themselves out of this unbridled and unlimited proposition of Master Calvins, let others judge?

There is just cause, I presume, to except against Master Calvin, and all others who in this concurre with him, to omit the tearme of Blasphemie in their definition, for that it is perpetually observed in the speech of our Saviour concerning this sinne by the Evangelists with one consent: but for the word Blasphemie, he hath brought into the definition the word resist for a genus of this sinne, but by what authority, I know not; I cannot find it, or the equivalent to it, in any of those places which are thought to touch this sinne: I find onely falling away mentioned Heb. 6. which phrase is used by Master Calvin for resisting, whereas falling away, and resisting, are no more like then fighting and running away, which are little lesse then contraries.

The last point I will touch in M. Calvins definition is that, where he saith, the sinners against the Holy-Ghost resist, to the end onely to resist, and yet withall he tells us, they resist out of a determined malice: if their resistance proceed from malice, then the end for which they resist, is the satisfaction of their malice. The Pharisees, who are condemned by our Saviour for this Crime, had another end, besides bare resisting;
the defence of the Law of Moses, was the end for which they Blasphemed, and not any pleasure they could take in the sole and simple act of resisting,
WEE find three old opinions concerning the sinne against the Holy-Ghost, but they were long since exploded, I will but onely name them.

First, Saint Origen thought all sinnes committed after Baptisme, to be sinnes against the Holy-Ghost: his reason w â€¢ s onely a wittie conceit of his owne; that God the Father is in all things, â€¢â€¢ e Sonne is onely in all reasonable creatures, the Holy Ghost is onely in all regenerate men therefore when men sinne against that Divine Person that is in them, if they be heathens, they sinne against God the Father, or the Sonne; if they be Christians, they sinne against the Holy-Ghost. The Novatian Heretiques agreed with Origen in opinion; for they denied remission of sinnes to any that fell, thinking all falls of Christians to be the sin against the Holy-Ghost: but this opinion is false; For else all sinnes were unpardonable to Christians: yet wee find Saint Paul remit the sinne of the incestuous Corinthian; also our Saviour chargeth the Pharisees with this sinne, who were no Christians.

Secondly, Saint Austin though finall impenitencie to be the sinne against the Holy Ghost; but finall impenitencie
is no Blasphemie, but onely a generall circumstance that may accompany any sinne. Besides, our Saviour intends, that this sinne may be found in this life; for he saith, it shall not be forgiven in this life, and the Pharisees were alive when they were accused of it.

Thirdly, P. Lombard, and T. Aquinas, thought sinnes of malice to be the sinne against the Holy-Ghost, and sinnes of infirmity against the Father, and sinnes of ignorance against the Sonne. This opinion is false, because the sinne against the Holy-Ghost must be a sinne of some certaine Blasphemie; but malice is no certaine sinne, but a generall, and it is not alwayes a Blasphemie.

The six differences the Schoole-men make of the sinne against the Holy-Ghost, are: First, Envying of our Brothers grace: Secondly, Impugning the Knowne Truth: Thirdly, Desperation, Fourthly, Presumption: Fifthly, Obstinacy: Sixthly, Finall impenitency.

In this Determination, of the Poynt of Blasphemy against the Holy Ghost, and the inquiry made into Master Calvins and others new definition of it; I hope I have delivered nothing contrary to the Doctrine of the Articles of the Church of England.
